### PR summary [2df7b1e4c8](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21021/commits/2df7b1e4c8f63fe1a65066a2deb46f2d05fef39d)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Spectrum.Prime.ChevalleyComplexity` (new file)|1648|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ BasicConstructibleSetData`
`+ chevalley_mvPolynomialC`
`+ chevalley_mvPolynomial_mvPolynomial`
`+ chevalley_polynomialC`
`+ degBound_casesOn_succ`
`+ degBound_le_degBound`
`+ degBound_pos`
`+ degBound_succ`
`+ degBound_zero`
`+ instance : DecidableEq (BasicConstructibleSetData R) := Classical.decEq _`
`+ map_comp'`
`+ map_id'`
`+ numBound_casesOn_succ`
`+ numBound_mono`
`+ numBound_succ`
`+ numBound_zero`
`++ numBound`
`++- map`
`++- map_comp`
`++- map_id`
`++- toSet`
`++- toSet_map`
`+-++ degBound`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>Increase in tech debt: (relative, absolute) = (1.00, 0.00)</summary>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|1166|1|erw|

Current commit [2df7b1e4c8](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/2df7b1e4c8f63fe1a65066a2deb46f2d05fef39d)
Reference commit [8deb89281c](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/8deb89281cb9880d8b820a009446ca9a3a58bdcb)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#21362~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!

:v: YaelDillies can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thank you everyone for the reviews! This is a great milestone.

bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13907062026/job/38912495310)
Canceled.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13908478322/job/38916972255)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13908478322/job/38916971866)
bors d+
I went through most of the overall strategy and docstrings, but I yet have to have a closer look at the proofs, which I'll hopefully find time to do before the end of the week.
bors d+

Would it be worthy to try to track degree and number of open sets separately?
(I'd say yes: in some parts of AG, it's useful to know that some varieties are defined by equations of degree 2.)

Do you mean "number of polynomials" rather than "number of open sets"? We're tracking the former, not the latter.

Given the shape of the bound (a tower of size depending on both the degree and number of polynomials used to describe the original variety), I doubt it is possible to track both variables independently.

Maybe what Antoine is asking, is to have separate bounds on the degree and the number of polynomials, not necessarily independent of each other? In this case, it seems that this is what actually happens in `chevalley_mvPolynomial_mvPolynomial`, but this doc string does suggest something else, namely that there is only one `M` bounding both the number of polynomials and degrees. Could you clarify this in this docstring?

Yes, I wrote the docstring informally because the fact that there is a bound is all that matters, really. `chevalley_mvPolynomial_mvPolynomial` features two bounds solely because we can't (usefully) make those bounds into one due to mutual recursion.
What property is there for `PrimeSpectrum` that makes this true and not for more general topological spaces?

It's the presence of a basis consisting of compact sets whose pairwise intersections are compact too. See https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/0069

Note that the general case is already proved: it's `IsTopologicalBasis.isRetrocompact_iff_isCompact` and we're using it here
Actually, it's equivalent to there being a basis of compact sets and the space being quasi-separated. See #21325.
This name does not follow the naming convention, right? Maybe `MvPolynomial.exists_constructibleSetData_image_eq`? Similarly above.
Also, could you please make sure that the `n` and `m` subscripts in the docstring correspond to LHS and RHS in the statement?
It follows the semantic naming convention instead of the symbol-reading naming convention, yes
I trust you that there is such a semantic naming convention, but I think I have never encountered it. At least not, where the actual common theorem name appears in the mathlib declaration.
It is only used in complicated named theorems whose symbol-read name would be too long/incomprehensible
This does not exist (yet), right?
It did exist, but then @erdOne removed it from this PR ðŸ˜…

This sentence seems to suggest that constructible sets in a prime spectrum are always open, which is not the case. Also, what do you mean by "polynomial" here? `R` is here still just an arbitrary ring, right?
I've added "(using unions, intersections, and complements)" to "made of open sets"

```suggestion
/-- The measure that will decrease during the induction in the `C : R â†’ R[X]` case of
Chevalley's theorem with complexity bound. -/
```

I am also confused by "open set" here. Should it be closed set? Or "if its complement can be written ..."?
Maybe it makes sense to stick to the presentation you used in [PrimeSpectrum.ConstructibleSetData](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Spectrum/Prime/ConstructibleSet.html#PrimeSpectrum.ConstructibleSetData)? Right now, I find it hard to match your high level description here up with the docstring of `chevalley_mvPolynomial_mvPolynomial`.
Yes actually you're right
What do you think of defining projections `ConstructibleSetData.f`, `ConstructibleSetData.n` and `ConstructibleSetData.g` to make these `x.2.1` less hard to parse?

`C` isn't of type `ConstructibleSetData, though. Do you instead mean turning
```
abbrev ConstructibleSetData := Finset (R Ã— Î£ n, Fin n â†’ R)
```
into
```
abbrev ConstructibleSetData := Finset (CustomStruct R n)
```
?
Oops, yes, that's what I head in mind.
This is not `p.coeffs`, because it contains `0`. Is there a reason why you want to have `0` in there?

This doesn't really matter either way because we're taking the submodule generated by the coefficients. The current definition is simply more convenient because `p.coeff i âˆˆ coeff(p)` (instead of `p.coeff i âˆˆ Submodule.span Râ‚€ coeff(p)`)

```suggestion
/-- The bound on the degree of the polynomials used to describe the constructible set appearing in the
case of `C : R â†’ R[X]` of Chevalley's theorem with complexity bound. -/
```

```suggestion
describe the constructible set appearing in the case of `C : R â†’ R[X]` of Chevalley's theorem with
complexity bound. -/
```

```suggestion
  âˆ€ f : R[X], âˆƒ T : ConstructibleSetData R,
    comap Polynomial.C '' (zeroLocus (Set.range e.val) \ zeroLocus {f}) = T.toSet âˆ§
    âˆ€ C âˆˆ T, C.2.1 â‰¤ e.degBound âˆ§ âˆ€ i, C.2.2 i âˆˆ e.coeffSubmodule Râ‚€ ^ e.powBound
```
I don't think this is used? You seem to write `e.val i` everywhere instead.
Good point, fixed
Why is this `private`? This might possibly be independently useful? (Probably without the type synonym `InductionObj` though).
It feels very very specialised to me, like the way you eliminate the polynomials by moding out with the lowest degree polynomial
I agree it is very unlikely and I don't have a strong opinion on it. It seems odd to me though that `InductionObj` is not also private then. Or is that one used in a public declaration?
Previously, making `InductionObj` private caused dot notation on it to fail. Looks like this is not the case anymore as of v4.18.0-rc1?

```suggestion
/-- Part 4 of the induction structure applied to `Statement Râ‚€ R n`. See the docstring of `induction_structure`. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- The bound on the degree of the polynomials used to describe the constructible set appearing in the
```

```suggestion
at most `M`* if it can be written as `(Câ‚ âˆª ... âˆª Câ‚–) \ D` where `k â‰¤ M`, `Câ‚, ..., Câ‚–` are closed
```
Is `U` the best letter here? It suggests "open" to me.
Whoops no, they were previously open

```suggestion
  toLex (Polynomial.degree âˆ˜ e, Â¬ âˆƒ i, (e i).Monic âˆ§ âˆ€ j, e j â‰  0 â†’ (e i).degree â‰¤ (e j).degree)
```
Please make the subscripts on the `hP` assumptions match the 1,2,3,4 in the docstring.

Afaict, this file does not actually contain a proof of this exact statement. But it is an easy corollary of the main result at the bottom of the file.
If my understanding is correct, please indicate so in this module doc.
Please add pointers to Lean declaration names in the above module doc, or add a section `## Main declarations`.
I would expect this to be the first condition...

Sorry for nitpicking, but now there are two uses of `C` in the same sentence. One solution might be
```suggestion
We first show the result in the case of `C : R â†’ R[X]`. We prove this by induction on the number of
components of the form `(Câ‚ âˆª ... âˆª Câ‚–) \ D`, then by induction again on the number of polynomials used to
describe `(Câ‚ âˆª ... âˆª Câ‚–)`. See the (private) lemma `chevalley_polynomialC`.
```
